title: 115_hr2924
content: The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to establish the National Russian Threat Response Center. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to establish the National Russian Threat Response Center within the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. Its primary missions include analyzing and integrating intelligence on threats posed by Russia to national security, sovereignty, and economic activity, as well as coordinating efforts to counter Russian actions against the US and its allies. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to establish the National Russian Threat Response Center within the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. It aims to analyze threats posed by Russia to national security, sovereignty, and economic activity of the United States and its allies. The center coordinates efforts to counter Russian actions and develop policy recommendations for the President to detect, deter, and respond to these threats. The National Russian Threat Response Center, established within the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, aims to monitor and assess threats posed by Russia, examine propaganda and information operations, and identify gaps in addressing these threats across government agencies. The Director of the Center is appointed to lead these efforts. The Director of the National Russian Threat Response Center, appointed by the Director of National Intelligence, is responsible for ensuring government departments participate in the Center's mission and coordinating efforts to address threats posed by Russia. The Director of the National Russian Threat Response Center, appointed by the Director of National Intelligence, collaborates with the U.S. Government to establish intelligence collection requirements related to threats posed by Russia. The Center submits annual reports to congressional committees on threats to national security, political sovereignty, and economic activity. The National Russian Threat Response Center submits annual reports to congressional committees discussing threats, the government's ability to address them, progress in achieving missions, and recommendations for legislative actions. Reports are unclassified but may include a classified annex. Federal employees can be detailed to the Center on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis. Federal employees can be detailed to the National Russian Threat Response Center on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis for up to 8 years. The Director of National Intelligence can hire personal services contractors for up to 3 years if existing personnel resources are insufficient. The National Russian Threat Response Center allows for an extension of up to 1 additional year for exceptional circumstances. The authority is limited to employing not more than 10 US citizens or aliens as personal services contractors for specialized skills or urgent needs. Employees and contractors must have appropriate security clearances. A Board for the Center is established. The Board oversees the Center to ensure mission achievement. It consists of 6 members appointed by department heads. The Board oversees the Center with 6 members appointed by department heads from various federal agencies. The Board meets biannually and is convened by the Secretary of State's appointee. The Director of the Center may organize biannual conferences for international coordination against Russian threats. The Center established to address threats from Russia will terminate 8 years after enactment. The appropriate congressional committees are defined as the intelligence committees, Committee on Foreign Affairs, Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives, Committee on Foreign Relations, and Committee on Armed Services of the Senate. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents. The National Russian Threat Response Center, established under Section 119C of the National Security Act of 1947, may receive up to $10,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 for its operations. The Director of National Intelligence has the authority to transfer funds for this purpose. The National Security Act of 1947 allows for the transfer of funds to the National Russian Threat Response Center without reprogramming requirements under other laws.
